prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories: A US Army sergeant, previously located in South Korea, is currently in Russian custody, as per the US military. The Russian foreign ministry has stated that the charges against the individual are not connected to politics or espionage, but rather to a domestic crime. The 34-year-old soldier was not on official travel when apprehended in Vladivostok, Russia, on May 2nd. He was reportedly traveling through China to Russia for personal reasons, not related to his new assignment at Fort Cavazos, Texas. Russian media sources suggest that the soldier was visiting a woman he had a romantic relationship with. The soldier's mother has confirmed that he was in Russia to see his girlfriend. The US Army has stated that the soldier did not seek official approval for his travel to China or Russia, and there is no indication that he intended to stay in Russia. The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on May 3rd that the soldier was arrested for theft. He is being detained at a pre-trial facility and will appear in court at a later date. The US Army has contacted his family and the US Department of State is offering consular support. The US is aware of this case and other related matters concerning Russia, as reported by the National Security Council spokesman. Russia is also holding two other Americans, including Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, who was detained in March 2023 on espionage charges, and former US Marine Paul Whelan, who was sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020 on spying charges. Both men have declared their innocence, and the US government claims that the charges against them are groundless.

A sergeant in the United States Army, who was previously stationed in South Korea, is currently in the custody of Russian authorities, according to the U.S. military. The Russian foreign ministry has stated that the individual's charges are not associated with politics or spying, but are related to a non-political crime. This 34-year-old soldier was not on an official trip when he was taken into custody in Vladivostok, Russia, on May 2nd. He was supposedly traveling through China to Russia for personal reasons, unrelated to his new post at Fort Cavazos, Texas. Reports from Russian media outlets suggest that the soldier was visiting a woman he had a romantic relationship with. The soldier's mother has confirmed that he was in Russia to see his girlfriend. The U.S. Army has disclosed that the soldier did not request official permission for his travel to China or Russia, and there is no evidence suggesting that he planned to remain in Russia. On May 3rd, the Russian interior ministry notified the U.S. embassy in Moscow that the soldier was arrested for theft. He is being held at a pre-trial detention center and will be presented in court at a later date. The U.S. Army has reached out to his family and the U.S. Department of State is providing consular assistance. The U.S. is monitoring this case and other related matters concerning Russia, as reported by the National Security Council spokesman. Additionally, Russia is detaining two other Americans, including Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, who was arrested in March 2023 on allegations of espionage, and former U.S. Marine Paul Whelan, who was sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020 on charges of spying. Both men have proclaimed their innocence, and the U.S. government contends that the accusations against them are baseless.

The US Army has confirmed that the soldier did not seek authorization for his travels to China or Russia, and there is no evidence indicating he planned to reside in Russia. The Russian interior ministry notified the US embassy in Moscow on May 3rd about the soldier's arrest for theft, and he is currently held at a pre-trial detention center. The soldier's family has been contacted by the US Army, and the US Department of State is offering consular assistance. The National Security Council spokesman stated that the US is closely monitoring this situation and other related matters involving Russia. Moreover, Russia is detaining two other Americans: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter arrested in March 2023 on espionage charges, and Paul Whelan, a former US Marine serving a 16-year sentence since 2020 on spying charges. Both individuals have proclaimed their innocence, and the US government asserts that the accusations against them are baseless.

A sergeant in the US Army, aged 34, who used to be based in South Korea, is currently in custody in Russia. He was arrested by Russian authorities in Vladivostok on May 2nd, as per the Russian foreign ministry. The Russian government has claimed that the arrest is not politically motivated, but instead due to a minor, non-political infringement. This sergeant, who held no official role at Fort Hood, Texas, was on a personal trip, traveling from China to Russia. His mother has revealed that the purpose of his journey was to meet a woman he was romantically involved with. The US Army has verified that the soldier did not seek authorization for his travels to China or Russia, and there is no indication that he intended to settle in Russia. On May 3rd, the Russian interior ministry notified the US embassy in Moscow about the soldier's arrest for theft, and he is currently detained at a pre-trial detention facility. The soldier's family has been contacted by the US Army, and the US Department of State is providing consular assistance. The National Security Council spokesperson has stated that the US is closely monitoring this situation and other related matters involving Russia. Additionally, Russia is presently detaining two more American citizens: Evan Gershkovich, a Wall Street Journal reporter apprehended in March 2023 on suspicion of espionage, and Paul Whelan, a former US Marine serving a 16-year sentence since 2020 on charges of spying. Both have denied the allegations, and the US government asserts that the claims are baseless.
